title: 51-carat diamond dazzles crowds ahead of online auction
description:
(2 Aug 2017) LEADIN:
A large diamond is wowing crowds in Moscow ahead of an online auction later this year.
The 51.38-carat diamond is part of a dazzling $10 million USD collection, crafted from one large 179-carat rough diamond discovered in 2015.
STORYLINE: 
From the mines of Sakha to the bright lights of Moscow.
Part state-owned Russian diamond mining company Alrosa is unveiling the 'Dynasty', a dazzling collection of five diamonds expected to fetch around $10 million USD at auction.
The five sparkling diamonds have been cut and polished from one 179-carat rough diamond discovered in a mine in the northeast Russian republic of Sakha in 2015. 
Diamonds extracted from the Nyurbinskaya pipe in Sakha are thought to be 365-390 million years old.
The large diamond was named 'The Romanovs', after Russia's imperial royal family.
The collection took a year and a half to create.
"These are five diamonds, carved out of a unique diamond, which was extracted from one of our pipes in Nyurbinskaya," explains Alrosa president Sergey Ivanov.
Its centrepiece is a 51.38-carat traditional round brilliant-cut diamond, named 'The Dynasty'.
It's claimed to be the purest and most expensive of all large diamonds manufactured throughout Russian jewellery history.
"This is a unique diamond with exclusive purity, colour and transparency," says director of Diamonds Alrosa, Pavel Vinikhin.
"And such diamonds of extremely high quality have never before been produced throughout the whole history of Russia, including Imperial Russia, the Soviet Union and modern Russia."
Arlosa named the collection 'The Dynasty' in a bid to pay tribute to Russia's renowned jewellers.
Other diamonds in the collection are named after dynasties that played a crucial role in the development of Russian jewellery.
The second by weight, a 16.67-carat round brilliant-cut diamond, is named 'The Sheremetevs'. 
'The Orlovs' is a 5.05-carat oval diamond, 'The Vorontsovs' is a 1.73-carat pear-cut diamond and 'The Yusupovs' is a 1.39-carat diamond.
Diamonds Alrosa hope to fetch at least $10 million for this collection says Ivanov.
'The Dynasty' collection is set to visit Hong Kong and Israel before an online auction in November.
"We developed a new way of selling such a unique collection of diamonds, which is through an online auction on the Alrosa website through a screening format," explains Alrosa sales director Anna Fedotova.
"Registered clients will, after going through a background check, which is a necessary step to attract the right kind of clients to our organisation, will be able to place their bids from any place in the world."


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/9f5c72ba903d213e32830dcc447c6d48 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
